node.text:

node.title: This is the Story of How One Family Made it Out of Afghanistan

node.title: Jen Psaki Slams Erik Prince for Profiting Off Afghanistan Evacuation

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by NowThis Politics on September 01, 2021. May be an image of 2 people and text that says 'EU removes the U.S. from 'safe list' of countries traveling into Europe NOW THIS INIGINATORS @atp Mnsegeg'.

node.text:
The European Union on Monday removed the U.S. from a list of safe countries traveling into Europe as COVID-19 cases continue to surge across the country. The EU is encouraging authorities in Europe to reinstate mandatory quarantine and testing requirements, though the decision is ultimately up to individual countries. Many member states are requiring travelers to show proof of vaccination to waive quarantine requirements.⁠
⁠
⁠
#eu #unitedstates #covid19 #notsafe #pandemic #masks

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by NowThis Politics on September 01, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and text that says 'Florida Dept of Ed punishes school districts imposing mask mandates NOW THIS @at Galy map'.

node.text:
The Florida Department of Education is punishing two school districts for imposing mask mandates despite an earlier ruling from a Florida judge that said the state did not have the authority to ban mask requirements in schools.⁠
⁠
Two Florida school districts, Alachua and Broward counties, have been penalized, with their school board members' salaries withheld, for ignoring Gov. Ron DeSantis’ order banning mask mandates. Several other school districts have also implemented mask mandates. A judge had previously ruled that the administration did not have the power to bar school mask mandates, and DeSantis said he was appealing the decision.⁠
⁠
⁠
#florida #education #masks #covid19

node.text:
Texas' new restrictive abortion law took effect Wednesday following the Supreme Court's inaction on a request to block it. The Supreme Court could still rule on the emergency application from abortion providers, but for now, Texas will prohibit most abortions after six weeks of pregnancy and allow private citizens to sue anyone that assists a pregnant person with an abortion, including giving them a ride to a clinic. The anti-abortion law is one of the most restrictive in the country.⁠
⁠
⁠
#texas #abortion #scotus #supremecourt #politics

node.text:
On Monday, the FBI released its annual ‘Hate Crime Statistics’ report and found that there was a significant uptick in hate crimes in 2020, most prominently against Black and Asian Americans. ⁠
⁠
In compiling data from 15,000+ local law enforcement agencies, the FBI identified 7,759 hate crimes, an increase of almost 450 over 2019’s findings. 2020’s total tally also saw the highest number of incidents since 2008, which recorded 7,783. Moreover, the FBI’s 2020 stats are likely to be an undercount, given that more than 3,000 law enforcement agencies in the U.S. did not submit crime statistics.⁠
⁠
The FBI data shows that crimes targeting Black people increased from 1,930 to 2,755, a 40% increase from 2019. The amount targeting people of Asian descent leaped to 158 to 274, a 70% rise. When it came to the racial background of alleged hate crime perpetrators, the report identified 3,633 hate crimes by white suspects, 1,309 by Black suspects, and 1,080 cases of suspects of unknown racial backgrounds.⁠
⁠
Rep. Judy Chu, chair of the Congressional Asian Pacific American Caucus, told the Washington Post that the numbers in the FBI report are not even close to the complete picture. Hate crimes against the Asian American community, specifically, saw a rise coinciding with the COVID-19 pandemic, ignited in large part by the rhetoric of conservative leaders like former President Donald Trump who blamed China for the virus. According to Stop AAPI Hate, 6,600+ hate incidents against Asian people were reported from March 2020 to March 2021. In April, President Joe Biden signed the COVID-19 Hate Crimes Act, a bill that created mechanisms to improve law enforcement’s ability to identify and investigate hate crimes.⁠
⁠
⁠
#stophate #hatecrimes #covid19

node.text:
A new report from the Associated Press undercuts the claim from many conservative leaders that the DOJ has been harder on Capitol insurrectionists than it has toward people arrested during the protests that occurred in the wake of George Floyd’s murder in summer 2020.⁠
⁠
In reviewing more than 300 federal cases tied to last year’s events, the AP found that 120 people 'have pleaded guilty or were convicted at trial of federal crimes including rioting, arson, and conspiracy,' across the U.S. The report says that more than 70 of the people sentenced so far received 27 months in prison on average, while at least 10 were sentenced to 5 or more years. ⁠
⁠
Meanwhile, the AP’s research found that ‘only a handful of the nearly 600 people who’ve been charged in the insurrection have received their punishments so far,’ and only 3 insurrectionists have received incarceration sentences — with the outcome of many of the most serious cases stemming from the January 6 riot still pending.⁠
⁠
⁠
#insurrection #protests #politics #letsgetthefactsstraight
